dependent.value:
Intentional strength of turnout (measured on a 9-point semantic differential)

Individual voting intentions (measured by 3 items on 5-point Likert scales, e.g.: “The extent of the current competition between political parties encourages me to vote.”)

Anticipated voter participation at the federal elections (measured as nominal variable)

conditions.value:
Experimental group 1: valence frame on increased party heterogeneity
Participants will read a short newspaper excerpt, which claims political parties to be “increasingly distinguishable” and that this “makes it easier for voters to orient themselves in the political landscape”.

Experimental group 2: valence frame on increased party homogeneity
Participants will read a short newspaper excerpt, which claims political parties to be “increasingly difficult to distinguish” and that this “makes it harder for voters to orient themselves in the political landscape”.

Experimental group 3: neutral frame on increased party heterogeneity
Participants will read a short newspaper excerpt, which claims political parties to “move further apart in their contents”.

Experimental group 4: neutral frame on increased party homogeneity
Participants will read a short newspaper excerpt, which claims political parties to “move closer together in their contents”.

hypothesis.value:
Does framing of party heterogeneity affect voting intentions?
Main hypotheses:
o	Party heterogeneity increases voting intentions (compared to party homogeneity).
o	Valence framing on increased party heterogeneity increases voting intentions (compared to a neutral frame).
o	Valence framing on increased party homogeneity decreases voting intentions (compared to a neutral frame).

attributes.title: Effect of convalescent blood products for patients with severe acute respiratory infectious of viral etiology: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression.

q1.value: Effect of convalescent blood products for patients with severe acute respiratory infectious of viral etiology: A systematic review, meta-analysis and meta-regression.

q4.value: Compared to placebo or traditional care, could convalescent blood products decrease mortality of patients with severe acute respiratory infectious of viral etiology?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: In December 2019, a series of pneumonia cases with unknown causes appeared in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, with fever, dry cough, and fatigue as the main clinical manifestations. The novel coronavirus was identified by deep sequencing of lower respiratory tract samples. The International Committee on virus classification named the new virus SARS-CoV-2. The World Health Organization named the disease caused by the virus as Coronavirus Disease 2019. In the latest novel coronavirus pneumonia diagnosis and treatment plan (trial version 7) from China, "convalescent plasma therapy" is classified as one of the treatment methods for heavier and critical patients, and has aroused wide attention from all of the world. Because we know little about the Coronavirus Disease 2019, we could only conclude the application of convalescent blood products in other severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology, hoping to provide a theoretical basis for the treatment of patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: The interventional and control groups had to have included hospitalized patients with a diagnosis of severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology, and investigators had to report mortality rates or the timing of initiation of convalescent blood product therapy. We will not exclude the children, pregrant women. Duplicates, studies did not focused on severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiolog patients, studies did not provide the outcomes which we need and those articles which did not clearly compare the convalescent blood with the standar care (or placebo) will be excluded. We will e-maile the corresponding authors of the eligible articles for further details, if available. Any uncertainty will be resolved by discussion with the third researcher. Studies had to have used convalescent blood products like whole blood, plasma, serum or hyperimmune immunoglobulin obtained from humans who had recovered from severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology as the treatment product and had to indicate the type, route and treatment strategy of convalescent blood products which were applied among patients. In the control groups, patients should be applied placebo or gave patients standard treatment without convalescent blood products.

q13.value: The literature systematically searched yielded 17456 references in five electronic databases that were subsequently refined to 17 eligible studies for further consideration which included three RCTs, one prospective cohort study, three retrospective comparison studies and 10 case series.

question.value: The primary outcome is mortality. The secondary outcomes are adverse events and the effect of earlier initiation of convalescent blood products among patients with severe acute respiratory infections of viral etiology.

Two reviewers will independently extracte data from included trials and assesse for eligibility by them. Document screening by reading the title, abstract, and full text. The abstracted data includes the name of first-author, year of publication, country, the number of ICU in each trial, study method, viral aetiology, type of convalescent blood products, treatment strategy, timing of initiation of convalescent blood products, sample size, intervention description, transfusion-related adverse events. If any of these data is inadequate, we will contact the corresponding authors by e-mail. Any uncertainty will be resolved by discussion with the third researcher.
The risk of bias in eligible RCTs or prospective cohort studies will be examined by the Cochrane Collaboration risk of bias tool.Trials will be rated as"low," "unclear," or "high" in several domains. Two investigators will evaluate the bias from random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of participants and personnel, blinding of outcome assessment, incomplete outcome data, selective reporting and other bias. The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) will be selected to judge the quality of retrospective cohort studies which concentrates on three aspects: selection, comparability, and outcome (range 0−9 stars). Disagreements between the review authors over the risk of bias in any study will be resolved by discussion, with involvement of a third review author where necessary.
We will generate summary estimates of mean and standard deviation (SD) for continuous outcomes. Values for dichotomous results are given as the odds ratios (OR) with 95% CI. A random-effects model will be used due to the significant heterogeneity identified between studies, otherwise, the fixed effects model will be performed. We will pool data of dichotomous by Mantel-Haenszel (M-H) statistical models. Results will be adjusted by adding 0.5 to each cell of the contingency table when no deaths occurred in the interventional group in individual trials. The estimation of effect will be summarized by the forest plot. The value of P < 0.05 is considered statistically significant for all research. I² testing will be applied to assess the heterogeneity between trials (where a value of >50% is regarded as indicating substantial heterogeneity). Sensitivity analyses will be conducted by sequentially omitting one study each time to identify the potential influence. We will judge the publication bias for the outcomes which contained more than five trials by creating a funnel plot and applying traditional statistical methods (Egger's test). Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) approach will be applied to judge the quality of evidence for the primary and secondary outcomes. Meta-regression using a random-effects model analysis will be performed to reveal the potential covariates of studies if there is any statistically significant or methodological heterogeneity. The investigators will construct meta-regression by using the following aspects as covariates: publication year, race, article sample size, the proportion of male (%), mean age, Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score, Acute Physiology, and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) II score. The statistical analyses will be completed using Review Manager Version 5.3, Stata version 15.1 and GRADE Profiler version 3.6.
For subgroup analysis, the following variables will be selected before the study is undertaken: study method (RCT or cohort study); different viral aetiology(SARS virus, Infuenza A virus, Ebola virus, or MERS Virus); type of convalescent blood products( plasma, serum, hyperimmune immunoglobulin or whole blood); timing of initiation of convalescent blood products (earlier versus later). A test of interaction will be performed on all subgroups to determine whether the difference between subgroups is statistically signiﬁcant.

attributes.title: The Role of Personality and Government Transparency in Response to COVID-19

q1.value: The Role of Personality and Government Transparency in Response to COVID-19

q2.value: Meghan Siritzky, Sara J. Weston, David M Condon

q3.value:
The purpose of the current study is to examine the degree to which the government responses in different countries impact psychological distress during an infectious disease outbreak. We also want to investigate the role of personality in impacting psychological distress during an infectious disease outbreak. The results could potentially tell us the types of people that are more likely to have certain psychological responses, and which types of government responses are more likely to alleviate or exacerbate psychological distress, under the circumstances of an infectious disease outbreak. Furthermore, these results have considerable public policy implications, as they could shed light on which individuals pose a risk to the general public based on their lack of engagement in preventive health behaviors and lack of compliance with government recommendations and policies.

Research questions: 
1. How do individual differences in perception of the government’s response to an infectious disease outbreak relate to individual responses to an outbreak?
2. How do individual differences in personality relate to individual responses to an infectious disease outbreak?
3. How does country-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to country-level political and economic differences?

q4.value:
1. Younger age, lower education level, lower trust in government, higher risk perception, and higher neuroticism will be associated with higher anxiety and depression during a COVID-19 outbreak (in line with findings from Kang et al., 2018; Lung et al., 2009; McAlonan et al., 2007; Taylor et al., 2008; Xie et al., 2011).
2. Older age, higher education level, being female, full-time employment, higher anxiety, higher risk perception, higher trust in government, higher risk perception, and lower perceived personal controllability will be associated with engaging in more preventive health behaviors during a COVID-19 outbreak (in line with findings from Bish & Michie, 2010; Gaygısız et al., 2012, Lau et al., 2007; Leung et al., 2003; Li et al., in preprint; van der Weerd et al., 2011).
3. Higher conscientiousness, older age, and lower education level will be associated with higher risk perception and lower perceived personal controllability of risk during a COVID-19 outbreak (in line with findings from Commodari, 2017).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The current study is a cross-sectional observational study that will use self-report measures of traits, attitudes, psychological states, and behaviors.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The primary participants will be individuals recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk from the following countries: USA, Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, China, Israel, Qatar, Iran, Italy, and Germany. It is expected that the measures will take 15m00s to complete. All participants will receive $1.00 for their participation. All participants will be 18 years of age or older. We do not expect any participants over 118 years of age to participate. Participants will participate online and will participate only once (i.e. the survey includes only one session of data collection and is expected to be completed in one sitting). Responses to the surveys completed by the participants will be recorded through Qualtrics.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 200 participants per country. At most, data on 2000 participants will be collected.

q14.value: A sample size of 200 gives us 90% power to detect correlations as small as 0.23. We only have the resources to administer this test to approximately 2000 individuals, so this sample size gives us a good chance of detecting a moderate effect for that amount of resources.

q15.value: We will continue recruiting participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk until we have 200 participants per country, or until we have collected data for three successive weeks, whichever comes first (i.e. if we do not have 200 participants in a given country by the end of the three week point after data collection has begun, we will stop data collection in that country).

question.value: Participants will complete the following measures, comprising 100 items: (1) BFI-2-S, a measure of the Big Five Inventory of personality (Soto & John, 2017), (2) IUS-12, a measure of intolerance of uncertainty (Carleton et al., 2007), (3) adapted measures of trust in government, government preparedness, government performance, (Freimuth et al., 2017; Lau et al., 2010; Murtin et al., 2018), (4) a PROMIS Anxiety 4-item measure (Pilkonis et al., 2011), (5) a PROMIS Depression 4-item measure (Pilkonis et al., 2011), (6) an adapted measure of preventive behaviors (Betancourt et al., 2016; Lau et al., 2010), (7) an adapted measure of risk perception (Lau et al., 2010), (8) an adapted measure of perceived controllability (Li et al., in preprint), and (9) demographic data (e.g. gender, age, household income, country of residence). Other country-level measures that will be considered are (1) Integrated Network for Societal Conflict Research (INSCR) Regime Authority Characteristics and Transitions datasets and State Fragility Index and Matrix datasets, (2) GINI indices from The World Bank, (3) publicly available stock market information, and (4) the Freedom House Freedom in the World 2020 report.

We will average the items for each respective scale into a total score for participants. We will calculate a total score for the BFI-2-S, IUS-12, PROMIS-Anxiety, PROMIS-Depression, risk perception, trust in government, government preparedness, government performance, and government compliance measures. The perceived controllability items will not be averaged, and will be examined individually as individual perceived controllability and government perceived controllability. The preventive behaviors will not be averaged, but will instead be added to create a total score for participants, and more granular exploratory analyses will be done on individual items. 

The trust in government, government preparedness, and government performance measures will be averaged to create a total score for perception of government response, but analyses will be done on both the total score and with the average of each of these measures as facet scores.

To test social distancing behaviors, we will add the items of “avoided physical contact with people outside of your immediate family,” “avoided visiting crowded places,” “avoided traveling abroad,” and “stopped leaving the house for work” to create a total score for participants.

For all the multiple regression models, we will use multilevel modeling to nest participants within country; country intercepts and slopes will be allowed to vary. Predictions of these intercepts and slopes will constitute exploratory analyses if and only if we successfully sample 25 participants each from at least 5 countries. Using these multilevel models, we will use the statistical tests of the fixed effects to test the following hypotheses:

To test Hypothesis 1, we will use fixed effects to estimate (a) anxiety scores and (b) depression scores from the participants’ age, education level, trust in government scores, risk perception scores, and BFI-2-S neuroticism scores. 

To test Hypothesis 2, we will use fixed effects to estimate engaging in preventive health behaviors from the participants’ age, education level, gender, employment status, anxiety scores, risk perception scores, and perceived personal controllability scores.

To test Hypothesis 3, we will use fixed effects to estimate (a) risk perception and (b) perceived personal controllability of risk from the participants’ age, education level, and BFI-2-S conscientiousness scores.

q20.value: There are no planned transformations to the data.

q21.value: For the multiple regression predictors, a p-value of 0.05 (two-tailed) will be used with a Holm correction for multiple comparisons. This correction will be applied to all hypothesis tests within a research question.

q22.value: Participants with a response standard deviation under 0.5 and/or a completion time under 30 seconds will be excluded. For any analyses involving gender as a variable, participants who do not identify as either a woman or a man will be excluded. Outliers will be retained in our analyses.

q23.value: Incomplete responses will be discarded. This includes participants who do not click through the debriefing form and do not get paid for their responses.

q24.value:
Additional exploratory analyses will be conducted to investigate the relations among measured variables that are relevant to the ten research questions outlined below, using multilevel modeling with participants nested within countries. We will also conduct within-country analyses if we have at least 150 participants in a given country. Additional analyses may be conducted investigating the relations among measured variables that have not been outlined in the research questions. If included in the final manuscript, all of these analyses will be explicitly described as exploratory. 

1. How do individual differences in perception of the government’s response to an infectious disease outbreak relate to individual responses to an outbreak?
1a. How does individual-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to personal mental health outcomes during a COVID-19 outbreak?
1b. How does individual-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to compliance with government recommendations and policies during a COVID-19 outbreak?
1c. How does individual-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to risk perception and perceived controllability of risk during a COVID-19 outbreak?
1d. How does individual-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to engaging in preventive health behaviors during a COVID-19 outbreak?
2. How do individual differences in personality relate to individual responses to an infectious disease outbreak?
2a. How does personality relate to personal mental health outcomes during a COVID-19 outbreak?
2b. How does personality relate to compliance with government recommendations and policies during a COVID-19 outbreak?
2c. How does personality relate to risk perception and perceived controllability of risk during a COVID-19 outbreak?
2d. How does personality relate to engaging in preventive health behaviors during a COVID-19 outbreak?
2e. How does personality relate to individual-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak?
3. How does country-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to country-level political and economic differences?

3. How does country-level perception of the government’s response to a COVID-19 outbreak relate to country-level political and economic differences?
registration_responses.q8.question: The current study is a cross-sectional observational study that will use self-report measures of traits, attitudes, psychological states, and behaviors.
registration_responses.q12.question: The primary participants will be individuals recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk from the following countries: USA, Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, China, Israel, Qatar, Iran, Italy, and Germany. It is expected that the measures will take 15m00s to complete. All participants will receive $1.00 for their participation. All participants will be 18 years of age or older. We do not expect any participants over 118 years of age to participate. Participants will participate online and will participate only once (i.e. the survey includes only one session of data collection and is expected to be completed in one sitting). Responses to the surveys completed by the participants will be recorded through Qualtrics.
registration_responses.q17.question: Participants will complete the following measures, comprising 100 items: (1) BFI-2-S, a measure of the Big Five Inventory of personality (Soto & John, 2017), (2) IUS-12, a measure of intolerance of uncertainty (Carleton et al., 2007), (3) adapted measures of trust in government, government preparedness, government performance, (Freimuth et al., 2017; Lau et al., 2010; Murtin et al., 2018), (4) a PROMIS Anxiety 4-item measure (Pilkonis et al., 2011), (5) a PROMIS Depression 4-item measure (Pilkonis et al., 2011), (6) an adapted measure of preventive behaviors (Betancourt et al., 2016; Lau et al., 2010), (7) an adapted measure of risk perception (Lau et al., 2010), (8) an adapted measure of perceived controllability (Li et al., in preprint), and (9) demographic data (e.g. gender, age, household income, country of residence). Other country-level measures that will be considered are (1) Integrated Network for Societal Conflict Research (INSCR) Regime Authority Characteristics and Transitions datasets and State Fragility Index and Matrix datasets, (2) GINI indices from The World Bank, (3) publicly available stock market information, and (4) the Freedom House Freedom in the World 2020 report.
registration_responses.q18.question:
We will average the items for each respective scale into a total score for participants. We will calculate a total score for the BFI-2-S, IUS-12, PROMIS-Anxiety, PROMIS-Depression, risk perception, trust in government, government preparedness, government performance, and government compliance measures. The perceived controllability items will not be averaged, and will be examined individually as individual perceived controllability and government perceived controllability. The preventive behaviors will not be averaged, but will instead be added to create a total score for participants, and more granular exploratory analyses will be done on individual items. 

The trust in government, government preparedness, and government performance measures will be averaged to create a total score for perception of government response, but analyses will be done on both the total score and with the average of each of these measures as facet scores.

To test social distancing behaviors, we will add the items of “avoided physical contact with people outside of your immediate family,” “avoided visiting crowded places,” “avoided traveling abroad,” and “stopped leaving the house for work” to create a total score for participants.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For all the multiple regression models, we will use multilevel modeling to nest participants within country; country intercepts and slopes will be allowed to vary. Predictions of these intercepts and slopes will constitute exploratory analyses if and only if we successfully sample 25 participants each from at least 5 countries. Using these multilevel models, we will use the statistical tests of the fixed effects to test the following hypotheses:

To test Hypothesis 1, we will use fixed effects to estimate (a) anxiety scores and (b) depression scores from the participants’ age, education level, trust in government scores, risk perception scores, and BFI-2-S neuroticism scores. 

To test Hypothesis 2, we will use fixed effects to estimate engaging in preventive health behaviors from the participants’ age, education level, gender, employment status, anxiety scores, risk perception scores, and perceived personal controllability scores.

To test Hypothesis 3, we will use fixed effects to estimate (a) risk perception and (b) perceived personal controllability of risk from the participants’ age, education level, and BFI-2-S conscientiousness scores.

attributes.title: Pathways for Change
attributes.description: New Zealand’s emerging adult suicide rates are consistently among the highest in the OECD. Although commonly referred to as our best and brightest, tertiary students are not immune to these statistics. Despite the growing support for Interpersonal Theory of Suicide, to date, only two studies have sought to empirically test the three-way interaction in a tertiary sample, and, no research has tested the theory within a New Zealand context. Furthermore, despite efforts by Universities to develop effective suicide prevention policies, there appears to be a gap between the individuals and the support services offered by the University. One possibility is that current approaches may not adequately account for help-seeking barriers that students perceive to restrict their access to services. To better understand why some of our most vulnerable students have low levels of help seeking behaviours, we will also further test previous findings about why students, particularly those experiencing mental distress, tend not to seek support.

q1.value: Pathways For Change: Do Global Findings Regarding The Emergence Of Suicidal Thoughts And Behaviours, And Barriers To Help-Seeking Remain Consistent Among New Zealand Students?

q2.value: Andre Mason, Kenny Jang, Benjamin Riordan, Scarf Damian, Sunny Collings

q3.value: New Zealand’s emerging adult suicide rates are consistently among the highest in the OECD. Although commonly referred to as our best and brightest, tertiary students are not immune to these statistics. Despite the growing support for Interpersonal Theory of Suicide, to date, only two studies have sought to empirically test the three-way interaction in a tertiary sample, and, no research has tested the theory within a New Zealand context. Furthermore, despite efforts by Universities to develop effective suicide prevention policies, there appears to be a gap between the individuals and the support services offered by the University. One possibility is that current approaches may not adequately account for help-seeking barriers that students perceive to restrict their access to services. To better understand why some of our most vulnerable students have low levels of help seeking behaviours, we will also further test previous findings about why students, particularly those experiencing mental distress, tend not to seek support.

q4.value:
In line with the IPTS itself, and recent empirical literature (Ma, Batterham, Calear, & Han, 2016), we hypothesise that the two-way interaction between perceived burdensomeness and thwarted belonging would predict higher levels of suicidal ideation. Additionally, we hypothesise that the three-way interaction between perceived burdensomeness, thwarted belonging, and capability for suicide would predict higher levels of suicide attempts.

Drawing on earlier findings (Bruffaerts et al., 2019; Czyz et al., 2013), we hypothesise that students will be less likely to endorse reasons directly related to stigma and are more likely to endorse reasons that are more nuanced when describing why they would not seek help.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional, observational

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Students who are interested in taking part will first be provided with information about the study through the University of Otago's Department of Psychology’s research portal. If they choose to participate, students will be required to complete a brief survey using the online survey platform. Qualtrics. This survey will collect basic demographic information, as well as information relating to the key study constructs

Undergraduate psychology students at the University of Otago between 18 and 25 will be included. However, non-tertiary students and students who are not currently enrolled at the University of Otago. This is because the main aim of this study is to empirically test previous findings using a tertiary sample and also, to have consistency for support services that are specific to University of Otago students (e.g. Student Health).

q13.value: This study aims to recruit as many undergraduate university students as possible.

q14.value: Data was simulated using the broom (Robinson & Hayes, 2019) and purrr (Henry & Wickham, 2019) packages in R. Based on results from Becker et al. (2020), these simulations yield a minimum sample size of n = 250 to achieve adequate power (power > .8).

question.value:
This study will contain three primary outcomes; suicidal thoughts, suicide attempts, and barriers to help seeking. 
We will also measure; thwarted belonging, perceived burdensomeness, depression, anxiety, capability for suicide, stigma for receiving psychological help and alcohol use.

In line with (Becker et al., 2020), the following approach will be used to address the first research question. Initially, the descriptive data and intercorrelations will be computed for the relevant factors; suicide risk, depression, thwarted belonging, perceived burdensomeness, fearlessness about death, and gender. Multiple linear regressions will then be used to test the three-way interaction between thwarted belonging, perceived burdensomeness, and fearlessness about death on suicide risk.

To address the second research question, the descriptive stats will be calculated at the first step. Chi-squared analyses will then be used to test whether responses differ between gender and between those with no mental disorder or suicidal thoughts and behaviours, with a mental disorder only, with suicidal thoughts or behaviours only, and with both a mental disorder or suicidal thoughts and behaviours. Ordinal logistic regressions will then be used to examine the odds ratios for group differences in ratings of the importance for each barrier.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining significance. Additionally, 95% CI's will be calculated and described.

q24.value: We expect that patterns of alcohol use may be related to differences in psychological variables (e.g. thwarted belonging, depression, anxiety) and thus, may contribute to differences in help-seeking and/or suicidal thoughts and behaviours. We will look for relationships between alcohol use and the variables included within this study, and the possibility of alcohol use acting as a mediator.

attributes.title: Film Elicitation
attributes.description: This project used film clips accompanied by context sentences to elicit basic and complex emotions in a laboratory setting. The project was aimed to initiate an iterative archive of film clips for future research.

summary.value: This study was conducted to initiate an iterative archive of film clips for eliciting the following emotions - amusement, anger, anxiety, compassion, contentment, disgust, fear, happiness/joy, irritation, neutrality, pride, relief, sadness, and surprise. Further validation is needed but the associated manuscript for this study will provide researchers a range of ratings to assist them in selecting potential film clips for use in their research.

attributes.title: Beauty is in the Race of the Beholder

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Beauty is in the Race of the Beholder

sample.value: Based on a power analysis using G*Power, our goal is to recruit 100 participants per condition.

analyses.value:
The DV in this study is a question that asks Asian, Black, and White participants about their explicit racial preferences.

Using R, we will run a logistic regression to determine whether gender (male, female), condition (outgroup1, outgroup2, control), and the interaction between these two variables predict participants' racial preferences. As covariates, we will include SDO, age, education, political views, and a racial prejudice measure.

outliers.value:
We will be recruiting participants who reside with the U.S., identify as solely Asian, Black, or White, and identify as heterosexual. We will exclude any participants from the final data analysis that report otherwise.

We also have two attention check measures that assess whether participants read the condition articles correctly.

Participants who fail any of the attention checks, or who do not complete the entire study, will be excluded from the dataset.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable we will be measuring is participants' explicit racial preferences.
Question: "If you had to choose to date from one of the following racial groups, which would you choose?"

conditions.value:
U.S. heterosexual Asian, Black, and White Participants will be asked whether they prefer to date from one of the given outgroups.

Condition 1 will present an article that explains that outgroup 1 has a racial preference for the participant and outgroup 2 doesn't.

Condition 2 will present an article that explains that outgroup 2 has a racial preference for the participant and outgroup 1 doesn't.

Control Condition will present an article that gives no information on outgroups' racial preferences.

hypothesis.value: Does manipulating participants' beliefs about the racial preferences of others shape their own racial preferences?

attributes.title: Perception of Objects in Relation to Human Desire
attributes.description: To replicate Balectis and Dunning's experiment on object perception. We will test whether participants see desirable objects as physically closer compared to neutral objects.

q1.value: Perception of Objects in Relation to Human Desire.

q2.value: Salome L. Boyd, Zhamari Seals, Haley  Pettingill

q3.value: People assume that their perception of the surrounding environment is a true representation of what exists. However, scholars in both philosophy and psychology have argued for centuries whether we accurately see what’s really there. Psychologists research this lingering question in a variety of ways, including, how do our physical brain structures work, do our previous expectations play a role in what we see, or can our subconscious unknowingly influence  perception. In this study, however, we replicated experiment one  from Balcetis and Dunning (2010), which focuses on the effect of thirst on the visual perception of water bottles. Our attitudes are constantly evolving, so do these shifting goals cause us to perceive the world differently?

q4.value: We expect that thirsty participants will rate the bottle of water as more desirable, and perceive it as closer, than quenched participants.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

We will collect data by asking participants to judge distances between themselves and water bottles. A one inch line will be the reference point. Outliers will be excluded from the data, however, will be noted of any excluded participants in the conclusion. We will ask participants to rate their thirst on a seven point Likert scale after judging distance.

attributes.title: Reducing Achievement Gaps at Scale Through a Brief Self-Affirmation Intervention
attributes.description: We propose to conduct a multisite randomized controlled trial (RCT) in a national sample of at least 6 districts to investigate the effectiveness of a virtually costless, scalable self-affirmation intervention designed to reduce stereotype threat and promote academic performance. The study design is a multisite student-level RCT implemented with two separate cohorts of seventh-grade students (2019‒20 and 2020‒21). Each year, we administer the first exercise at the beginning of school; three follow-up exercises occur just prior to a consequential evaluative activity. Power calculations assume 48 schools and 4,800 students, with a minimum detectable effect size of d = 0.10 for each cohort. Prior to randomization, during the first week of school, all seventh-grade students will complete a survey, with a follow-up survey shortly after receiving final administration of the intervention, and at the end of eighth grade.

q1.value: Reducing Achievement Gaps at Scale Through a Brief Self-Affirmation Intervention

q3.value:
We propose to conduct a multisite randomized controlled trial (RCT) in a national sample of at least 6 districts to investigate the effectiveness of a virtually costless, scalable self-affirmation intervention designed to reduce stereotype threat and promote academic performance. The self-affirmation intervention is theorized to buffer African American and Latino students from the harm of stereotype threat by affirming students’ core values in multiple domains. It consists of four 15-minute in-class writing exercises, which prompt seventh-grade students to choose two to three personally important values from a list of 11, including, for example, friends, family, music, religion, or sports, and to write about why these values are important to them. The precise format of the treatment exercise varies throughout the year to avoid repetition. 

The study design is a multisite student-level RCT implemented with two separate cohorts of seventh-grade students (2019‒20 and 2020‒21). Each year, we administer the first exercise at the beginning of school; three follow-up exercises occur just prior to a consequential evaluative activity. Power calculations assume 48 schools and 4,800 students, with a minimum detectable effect size of d = 0.10 for each cohort. Prior to randomization, during the first week of school, all seventh-grade students will complete a survey, with a follow-up survey shortly after receiving final administration of the intervention, and at the end of eighth grade.

The primary academic outcomes are student grades and standardized test scores, and the primary behavioral measures are student attendance and disciplinary records. Key measures of students’ academic attitudes and well-being include valuing academics, teacher expectations, locus of control, self-complexity, construal, belongingness, supportive relationships, self-control and evaluation anxiety. In addition, data will be collected that assess key moderating factors such as school-level racial bias and discrimination, and individual- and school-level perception of stereotype threat.

q4.value: The central hypothesis of this study is that the self-affirmation intervention will reduce achievement gaps (e.g., grade point average), and we answer that question by first testing whether there is an impact for all students (RQ1) and then assessing whether there is a differential impact for potentially threatened Latino and African-American versus other students (RQ2). Then, as is suggested by prior research, we will test which factors associated with the school context may also shape susceptibility to identity threat and the self-affirmation intervention’s corresponding effectiveness (RQ3).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: All coders of the intervention materials will be blind to the study hypothesis and to the treatment status of individual students.

question.value: The study design is a multisite student-level RCT implemented with two separate cohorts of seventh-grade students (2019‒20 and 2020‒21). Each year, we administer the first exercise at the beginning of school; three follow-up exercises occur just prior to a consequential evaluative activity. Prior to randomization, during the first week of school, all seventh-grade students will complete a survey, with a follow-up survey shortly after receiving final administration of the intervention, and at the end of eighth grade.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: Baseline survey and demographic data have been collected.  These data were collected prior to random assignment and have not been observed post-random-assignment.

question.value: All students in all sampled schools will be included in the study sample, unless a parent submits an "opt-out" form prior to data collection.  Only seventh grade students from each school will be sampled in each of the two years of data collection: 2019-20 and 2020-21.

q13.value: The study sample will include approximately 48 middle schools and two cohorts of approximately 4,800 seventh-grade students nested within the schools; 9,600 students in total. Cohort 1 will be tracked for three years (through ninth grade), and Cohort 2 will be tracked for two years (through eighth grade).

q14.value: Power calculations assume 48 schools and 4,800 students, with a minimum detectable effect size of d = 0.10 for each cohort.

q15.value: As a student-level random assignment study, our primary goal is to achieve a sample of 4,800 students per cohort.  The number of schools may be greater or lesser depending on achieving our student-level sample goals.

question.value:
The self-affirmation intervention is theorized to buffer African American and Latino students from the harm of stereotype threat by affirming students’ core values in multiple domains. It consists of four 15-minute in-class writing exercises, which prompt seventh-grade students to choose two to three personally important values from a list of 11, including, for example, friends, family, music, religion, or sports, and to write about why these values are important to them. The precise format of the treatment exercise varies throughout the year to avoid repetition. 

The randomly assigned control condition also focuses on values and requires the same amount of reading and writing but is not designed to deliver a self-affirming message. The control prompts ask students to select the two to three least important values from the same list read by treatment students and explain why they may be important to someone else.

We will collect the following student variables: Grade Point Average (GPA); Number of Ds and Fs; Reading and Math Standardized Test Scores; Student Behavioral Referrals; Student Attendance; and Social-Psychological Outcome Measures.  All measures are described in detail in: "OSF Affirmation student measures.docx".

We hypothesize positive impacts of assignment to the self-affirmation intervention for potentially threatened Latino and African-American students and null effects for White and Asian students. In addition, theory and evidence suggest that some school contexts amplify social-identity threats and that self-affirmation can be particularly beneficial within these contexts; for example, in those schools where racial group membership is salient and students occupy lower academic standing (see Borman et al., 2018). Therefore, although the first step in our proposed analyses is to examine the impact of assignment to the intervention for all students (RQ1), we will then turn to the influence of student-level factors (RQ2) and school-level factors (RQ3) on the outcomes.  Analytical models will take the form of yearly and longitudinal analyses, and will account for students nested within schools.  The specific functional form of the analyses can be found in the attached document: "OSF Affirmation analysis plan.docx".

registration_responses.q1: Reducing Achievement Gaps at Scale Through a Brief Self-Affirmation Intervention
registration_responses.q3:
We propose to conduct a multisite randomized controlled trial (RCT) in a national sample of at least 6 districts to investigate the effectiveness of a virtually costless, scalable self-affirmation intervention designed to reduce stereotype threat and promote academic performance. The self-affirmation intervention is theorized to buffer African American and Latino students from the harm of stereotype threat by affirming students’ core values in multiple domains. It consists of four 15-minute in-class writing exercises, which prompt seventh-grade students to choose two to three personally important values from a list of 11, including, for example, friends, family, music, religion, or sports, and to write about why these values are important to them. The precise format of the treatment exercise varies throughout the year to avoid repetition. 

The study design is a multisite student-level RCT implemented with two separate cohorts of seventh-grade students (2019‒20 and 2020‒21). Each year, we administer the first exercise at the beginning of school; three follow-up exercises occur just prior to a consequential evaluative activity. Power calculations assume 48 schools and 4,800 students, with a minimum detectable effect size of d = 0.10 for each cohort. Prior to randomization, during the first week of school, all seventh-grade students will complete a survey, with a follow-up survey shortly after receiving final administration of the intervention, and at the end of eighth grade.

The primary academic outcomes are student grades and standardized test scores, and the primary behavioral measures are student attendance and disciplinary records. Key measures of students’ academic attitudes and well-being include valuing academics, teacher expectations, locus of control, self-complexity, construal, belongingness, supportive relationships, self-control and evaluation anxiety. In addition, data will be collected that assess key moderating factors such as school-level racial bias and discrimination, and individual- and school-level perception of stereotype threat.
registration_responses.q4: The central hypothesis of this study is that the self-affirmation intervention will reduce achievement gaps (e.g., grade point average), and we answer that question by first testing whether there is an impact for all students (RQ1) and then assessing whether there is a differential impact for potentially threatened Latino and African-American versus other students (RQ2). Then, as is suggested by prior research, we will test which factors associated with the school context may also shape susceptibility to identity threat and the self-affirmation intervention’s corresponding effectiveness (RQ3).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

Cohort 1 will be tracked for three years (through ninth grade), and Cohort 2 will be tracked for two years (through eighth grade).

Prior to randomization, during the first week of school, all seventh-grade students will complete a survey, with a follow-up survey shortly after receiving final administration of the intervention, and at the end of eighth grade.
registration_responses.q12.question: All students in all sampled schools will be included in the study sample, unless a parent submits an "opt-out" form prior to data collection.  Only seventh grade students from each school will be sampled in each of the two years of data collection: 2019-20 and 2020-21.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The self-affirmation intervention is theorized to buffer African American and Latino students from the harm of stereotype threat by affirming students’ core values in multiple domains. It consists of four 15-minute in-class writing exercises, which prompt seventh-grade students to choose two to three personally important values from a list of 11, including, for example, friends, family, music, religion, or sports, and to write about why these values are important to them. The precise format of the treatment exercise varies throughout the year to avoid repetition. 

The randomly assigned control condition also focuses on values and requires the same amount of reading and writing but is not designed to deliver a self-affirming message. The control prompts ask students to select the two to three least important values from the same list read by treatment students and explain why they may be important to someone else.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will collect the following student variables: Grade Point Average (GPA); Number of Ds and Fs; Reading and Math Standardized Test Scores; Student Behavioral Referrals; Student Attendance; and Social-Psychological Outcome Measures.  All measures are described in detail in: "OSF Affirmation student measures.docx".
registration_responses.q19.question: We hypothesize positive impacts of assignment to the self-affirmation intervention for potentially threatened Latino and African-American students and null effects for White and Asian students. In addition, theory and evidence suggest that some school contexts amplify social-identity threats and that self-affirmation can be particularly beneficial within these contexts; for example, in those schools where racial group membership is salient and students occupy lower academic standing (see Borman et al., 2018). Therefore, although the first step in our proposed analyses is to examine the impact of assignment to the intervention for all students (RQ1), we will then turn to the influence of student-level factors (RQ2) and school-level factors (RQ3) on the outcomes.  Analytical models will take the form of yearly and longitudinal analyses, and will account for students nested within schools.  The specific functional form of the analyses can be found in the attached document: "OSF Affirmation analysis plan.docx".

attributes.title: Patient and caregiver education in dysphagia management: a scoping review
attributes.description:
Background: Texture-modified diets (TMDs) are common interventions for people with dysphagia. There is increased research investigating the implementation of standardized frameworks. One component of implementation of standardized frameworks is training and education of healthcare professionals, patients with dysphagia, and caregivers.

Objective: This study presents a scoping review of educational approaches to the management of TMDs to determine the breadth of research in the area, assess the representation of multiple stakeholders in the dysphagia management continuum and identify training approaches to TMD management in healthcare and community-based settings.

q1.value: Patient and caregiver education in dysphagia management: a scoping review

q2.value: David W Rule, Kathy J Welden, Leslie Stelzer, Anumitha Venkatraman

q3.value:
This scoping review aims to characterize training/education approaches for the management of dysphagia among patients with dysphagia and caregivers. The specific research questions are:
(1)	What formal or informal training/educational approaches exist with the specific purpose to build knowledge in management of dysphagia?
(2)	Of the educational approaches identified, what materials specifically consider texture-modified diets (TMDs)?
(3)	Of the educational resources investigated, what barriers to recommendation compliance/adherence are specifically mentioned?

q4.value: Given pilot search results, it is hypothesized that there will be few articles specifically addressing educational interventions pertaining to the topic of patient and caregiver education within dysphagia management.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This project will be conducted using PRISMA guidelines for scoping reviews. Literature searches of electronic databases will be conducted in databases relevant to the research topic including PubMed, CINAHL Plus, Health Source, Nursing/Academic Edition, PsychINFO, and MedLine. The search strategy will be developed by the PI with support from university library services and then will undergo a peer-review by a topic expert using the PRESS (Peer Review of Electronic Search Strategies) checklist. Search terms will be updated and reviewed again until consensus is achieved. Truncation will be used to capture relevant publications with varying morphological endings. Pearling will be used to scan publication reference lists for any additional relevant information meeting inclusion criteria.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: All human populations (adults/children) will be included in the literature search as dysphagia occurs across the life span across multiple etiologies. Populations receiving alternative nutrition such as a feeding tube will also be included. Inpatient, outpatient, and community-based settings will be considered in the review in order to capture the breadth of education/training opportunities for the dysphagia population. Training and education for patients, caregivers, and community members will be identified. Formal and informal educational approaches for TMD management in dysphagia populations will be addressed. All types of publications including published articles, articles in conference proceedings, editorials, and chapters in textbooks are relevant. No exclusion based on date of production will be implemented
Not applicable
See attached document
Not applicable
No statistical methods will be used; we will follow PRISMA guidelines for the dissemination of scoping review results
